title: Kathy Hochul Becomes Governor of New York, First Woman to Lead the State
sub_head: Democrat takes over from Andrew Cuomo, who resigned amid allegations of sexual harassment
body:
ALBANY, N.Y.—Kathy Hochul became the 57th governor of New York early Tuesday, making history as the first woman to serve as the state’s chief executive.
Ms. Hochul, a Democrat who has served as lieutenant governor since 2015, was sworn in just after midnight by New York State Court of Appeals Chief Judge Janet DiFiore during a ceremony at the State Capitol.
She succeeds Andrew Cuomo, who resigned in the face of impeachment proceedings and allegations of sexual harassment. Mr. Cuomo has denied he touched anybody inappropriately and said he stepped aside to prevent the government from being distracted.
Ms. Hochul, 62 years old, has said she would need around six weeks to build out an administration, and she has said she would appoint a lieutenant by the end of this week. She was communicating with several New York City politicians about the position, her advisers said.
The incoming governor on Monday named Karen Persichilli Keogh, a political aide who worked for Hillary Clinton during her time in the U.S. Senate, to the job of secretary, the top appointed position in the state.
